title-group.article-title: Robustness of feedback stabilization of quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian systems with parametric uncertainty

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanics, State Key Laboratory of Fluid Power Transmission and Control, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Wei-Qiu Zhu, Department of Mechanics, State Key Laboratory of Fluid Power Transmission and Control, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, People’s Republic of China Email: wqzhu@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The robustness of feedback stabilization for quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian systems with uncertain parameters is investigated. The uncertain parameters are modeled as bounded random variables with λ-probability density function. Based on the independence of uncertain parameters and stochastic excitations, a feedback control to asymptotically stabilize, with probability one, the nominal system (with average parameter values) is firstly obtained by applying the stochastic averaging method, the expression for the Lyapunov exponent of quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian systems and the stochastic dynamical programming principle. Then, the mean and standard deviations of the Lyapunov exponent of the uncertain quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian system are calculated by using the stochastic averaging method and probabilistic analysis. Finally, the robustness of the feedback stabilization for quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian systems with parametric uncertainty is evaluated in terms of the sensitivity of the variation coefficient of the Lyapunov exponent of a controlled system to the variation coefficients of uncertain parameters. An example is worked out to illustrate the robustness of the feedback stabilization.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In the last two decades, maximal Lyapunov exponent, instead of Lyapunov function, has been used to study the asymptotic Lyapunov stability with probability one of stochastic systems. The theoretical base of this usage is the Oseledec multiplicative theorem (Oseledec, 1968), which states that the necessary and sufficient condition for the asymptotic Lyapunov stability with probability one of a linear stochastic system is the negativeness of its maximal Lyapunov exponent. A combination approach of the stochastic averaging method for quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian systems (Zhu and Yang, 1997) and the Khasminskii theorem (Khasminskii, 1967) was proposed by Zhu to evaluate the maximal Lyapunov exponent of quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian systems and study their stability (Zhu, 2004a). Combining this approach and the stochastic optimal control theory, Zhu has also proposed an innovative strategy for the stochastic stabilization ofquasi non-integrable Hamiltonian systems (Zhu, 2004b).

In the above study of stochastic stabilization, system parameters are assumed to be deterministic and constant. However, in practice, system parameters are often uncertain or subject to perturbation. Thus, the robustness of stochastic stabilization of systems is a significant issue in stochastic control.

Robustness can be defined as the ability of a control system to retain its stability or a certain level of performance requirement in the presence of uncertainty. The uncertainty can be uncertain system parameters or unmodeled dynamics. In the literature of robustness analysis, there are two frameworks: the deterministic worst-case framework and the probabilistic framework. The classic robust control theory was developed in the deterministic worst-case framework and many useful techniques have been proposed to deal with the robustness analysis, such as the Kharitonov theorem (Kharitonov, 1978), the edge theorem (Barlett et al., 1988), structured singular value µ analysis (Doyle, 1982; Iorga et al., 2009), the gap metric (Foias et al., 1993; Georgiou and Smith, 1997) and so on. Recently the probabilistic robustness analysis framework has received growing attention (Chen et al., 2008; Field et al., 1996; Ray and Stengel, 1993; Stengel and Ray, 1991; Tempo et al., 1997). In these researches, the guaranteed probability of the robustness requirement is the central problem and generally evaluated by Monte Carlo simulation or other randomized algorithms.

In this investigation, we focus our attention on the parametric uncertainty, which can be categorized as aleatory uncertainty that can commonly be modeled as ‘random’ quantities (Oberkampf et al., 2004). This kind of uncertainty can be introduced by various sources, such as the manufacturing and assembly tolerances, material property variations, etc. Usually the uncertain parameters in engineering are uncertain-but-bounded in nature (Qiu and Wang, 2003), two types of representations of uncertain parameters, i.e., strong statistic information representation and intervals representation can be adopted, depending on the information about the uncertainty that can be obtained. For the strong statistic information case, the uncertain parameters can be modeled as bounded random variables with known probability density function (PDF). Although the commonly accepted models are the uniform distribution and the truncated Gaussian distribution (Barmish and Lagoa, 1997), they can both be incorporated into a new model called λ-probability density function (λ-PDF) distribution. This model was introduced by Fang and his co-workers to model a family of bounded, mono-peak, and symmetrical distributions and also applied to several uncertain structures recently (Fang et al., 2004; Ma et al., 2004). It was shown that λ-PDF can be used as a more reasonable model for bounded uncertain parameters.

In the present paper, the robustness of stochastic stabilization of quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian systems is studied. The uncertain parameters are modeled as bounded random variables with λ-PDF. The robustness is measured in terms of the sensitivity of the variation coefficient of the Lyapunov exponent of a controlled system to the variation coefficients of uncertain parameters. A procedure for evaluating the robustness is proposed and illustrated with an example.

sec.title: 2. λ-PDF and the uncertain parameters
sec.p:
A family of bounded PDFs with mono-peak and symmetrically distributed within [−1, 1], named as λ-PDF can be defined as follows (Fang et al., 2004) (1) where λ ≥ 0 is a parameter, and the normalizing coefficient aλ can be written as (2) in which Γ(·) is a Gamma function. Any PDFs with mono-peak and symmetrically distributed within [−1, 1] can be approximated by λ-PDF, provided that they are continuous and smooth. The graph of λ-PDF for different values of λ is shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
λ-PDF curves for different values of λ.

Suppose s = [s1, s2, …, sm]T is a vector of the uncertain parameters and has the following components: (3) where s¯r denote the mean values of uncertain parameters. ξr denote mutually independent random variables defined on [−1, 1] with given λr-PDF, and s~r are constant coefficients taken as the intensities of uncertainty, thus, sr∈[s¯r-s~r,s¯r-s~r],r=1,…,m. Then the definition domain of s can be denoted as s ∈ S, where S={[S1,S2,…,Sm]T|s¯r-s~r≤Sr≤ s¯r-s~r,r=1,…,m}. The random variables sr can then be denoted as sr(s¯r,s~r,λr), whose variances can be derived as (4) equation (4) shows that the larger the λr and the smaller the s~r, the smaller the variances of the uncertain parameters sr.

sec.title: 3. Feedback stabilization of the nominal system
sec.p: Consider an n-degree-of-freedom (n-d.f.) controlled quasi-Hamiltonian system with uncertain parameters governed by the following n pairs of equations of motion: (5) where Qi and Pi are generalized displacements and momenta, respectively; H′(Q, P, s) is twice differentiable Hamiltonian generally representing total system energy; cij(Q, P, s) are the coefficients of quasi linear dampings; fik(Q, P, s) are the amplitudes of stochastic excitations; ζk(t) are Gaussian white noises with zero means and correlation functions E[ζk(t)ζl(t+τ)]=2Dklδ(τ); ui(Q, P) represent feedback controls; s represents a vector of uncertain parameters defined in equation (3) which is independent of ζk(t). Assume that dampings, control forces and stochastic excitations are weak in the sense that energy increment in one cycle of vibration is small compared with the total energy of the system, i.e., cij = O(ɛ), fik = O(ɛ1/2), ui = O(ɛ), where ɛ is a small positive parameter, then system (5) is called weakly controlled uncertain quasi-Hamiltonian system. Thus, the stochastic averaging method can be applied to equation (5) (Zhu and Yang, 1997).

Equation (5) with the uncertain parameter vector s replaced by its mean vector s¯ is called nominal system. The Itô stochastic differential equations of the nominal system are (6) where H(Q,P,s¯) and mij(Q,P,s¯) are the new Hamiltonian and damping coefficients possibly modified by the Wong-Zakai correction terms; σik(Q,P,s¯) are the elements of matrix σ with σσT=2fDfT; Bk(t) are the standard Wiener processes. The Hamiltonian system with modified Hamiltonian H governed by equation (6) with H. Then equation (6) describes a weakly controlled quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian system of n-d.f. By applying the stochastic averaging method for quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian systems (Zhu and Yang, 1997) to equation (6), the partially averaged Itô stochastic differential equations of the nominal system (6) can be obtained as follows: (7) where B(t) is unit Wiener process; m¯(H(Q,P,s¯)) and σ¯(H(Q,P,s¯)) are drift and diffusion coefficients determined by (8)

Consider the one-dimensional controlled diffusion process H(t) governed by equation (7) in a semi-infinite time-interval [0, ∞). Assume that the stationary solution exists in the system. Then we may formulate an ergodic control problem: finding Markov feedback control law ui(Q, P) to minimize the expected average cost function (9) where u=[u1,u2,…,un]T; R is a positive definite matrix. Both R and f(H) are unknown and will be determined later. By applying the stochastic dynamical programming principle, the dynamical programming equation for this ergodic control problem can be established as follows: (10) where V = V(H) is called value function, (11) is the optimal average cost function and u* is the optimal control.

The optimal feedback control law is obtained by minimizing the right-hand side of equation (10) with respect to u as follows: (12) where (R-1)ij is the i, jth element of R-1. If R is a diagonal matrix with elements Ri, equation (12) can be reduced to (13) where there is no summation over the repeated subscript. Substituting equation (12) or (13) into equation (10) and averaging the terms involving ui * lead to the final dynamical programming equation. Assume that R is diagonal, the dynamical programming equation is of the form (14) where 〈·〉 denotes the averaging defined by the third equation of equation (8). For given f(H) and Ri, the optimal control ui * is obtained by using equation (13), where dV/dH is obtained from solving equation (14).
Substituting the obtained ui * into equation (7) to replace ui and averaging the term ui∂H/dPi lead to the following completely averaged Itô equation: (15) where (16)

According to the procedure proposed by Zhu (2004b), the Lyapunov exponent of the optimally controlled averaged system (15) can be obtained as follows: (17) while the Lyapunov exponent of the uncontrolled averaged system can be obtained from equation (17) with ui *=0, that is (18)

It can be argued that the Lyapunov exponent defined above is the first approximation of the maximal Lyapunov exponent of the original optimally controlled or uncontrolled quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian system (6) (Zhu, 2004b). The necessary and sufficient condition for the asymptotic stability with probability one of the trivial solutions of the optimally controlled or uncontrolled system (6) is that ν¯c or ν¯u is negative.

The problem of stochastic stabilization of quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian systems is to select f(H) and R such that ν¯c is negative for positive ν¯u and the absolute value of (ν¯c-ν¯u) is as large as possible.

sec.title: 4. Robustness of feedback stabilization
sec.p: By substituting the optimal feedback control law in equation (13) into equation (5) and making the possible modification by the Wong-Zakai correction terms, equation (5) becomes (19)

For a fixed s ∈ S, the averaged Itô stochastic differential equations of system (19) can be derived by using the stochastic averaging method (Zhu and Yang, 1997) as follows: (20) where the expressions of the averaged drift coefficient m¯ and diffusion coefficient σ¯ are similar to those in equation (8) except that s¯ is replaced by s.
The Lyapunov exponent of the optimally controlled or uncontrolled averaged system (20) is then obtained in a similar way as that leading to equation (17) or (18), i.e., (21) or (22) where (23)
The mean and variance of the maximal Lyapunov exponent of the optimally controlled averaged system (20) are (24) where p(s) is the PDF of s defined in equation (3).

The sensitivity of the variation coefficient σ(νc)/m(νc) of Lyapunov exponent to the variation coefficients σ(si)/s¯i of parameters si is then used to measure the robustness of the feedback stabilization of uncertain quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian systems. The smaller sensitivity implies the higher robustness. This sensitivity analysis for different uncertain parameters can also be utilized to identify the most important uncertain parameter, which may be of extreme importance for design and implementation of practical engineering control systems.

sec.title: 5. Example
sec.p: Coupled van der Pol systems can provide fundamental models for the dynamics of various physical, electromechanical, chemical and biological systems (Choubey, 2010). As a simple example of the proposed procedure for robustness evaluation, consider the feedback stabilization of two nonlinearly coupled van der Pol oscillators with parameter uncertainty subject to parametric excitations of Gaussian white noises both in the stiffness and damping terms. The equations of motion are of the form (25) where a and b are the coefficients of linear and nonlinear stiffness couplings, respectively; a, b, αi, βi and ek are assumed to be bounded uncertain parameters with definition similar to (3), which can be denoted as: ki(k¯i,k~i,λki), a(a¯,a~,λa), b(b¯,b~,λb), αi(α¯i,α~i,λαi), βi(β¯i,β~i,λβi) and ek(e¯k,e~k,λek). Denote the uncertain parameter vector as s=[k1,k2,a,b,α1,α2,β1,β2,e1,e2,e3,e4]T, its mean vector as s¯=[k¯1,k¯2,a¯,b¯,α¯1,α¯2,β¯1,β¯2,e¯1,e¯2, e¯3,e¯4]T.

The Hamiltonian associated with system (25) is (26) Since the Hamiltonian system with Hamiltonian H is generally non-integrable when b ≠ 0 and δ ≠ 0, 1, equation (25) describes a weakly controlled quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian system. Following equations (6) to (8), the partially averaged Itô stochastic differential equation for the controlled Hamiltonian of the nominal system can be derived as (27) where
(28) in which R(H, θ) is the solution of the following equation: (29)

Consider the semi-infinite time-interval ergodic control with the performance index defined as equation (9). The optimal control forces are of the form of equation (13) with i = 1, 2, that is (30) Thus, (31) Two cases 0 < δ < 1 and δ > 1 are discussed in the following.

sec.title: 5.1. Case 1: 0 < δ < 1
sec.p: In this case, m¯(H) and σ¯2(H) in equation (28) and 〈P1 2/(2R1)+P2 2/(2R2)〉 in equation (31) have the following asymptotic forms: (32) where (33) Since dV/dH is the solution of equation (14) with m¯(H) and σ¯2(H) defined by equation (32), f(H) and dV/dH as H → 0 should be of the following asymptotic form: (34) where f1 and C1 are constants. Substituting equations (31) to (34) into equation (14), C1 can be obtained as (35)
Substituting the optimal control in equation (30) into the uncertain system, the Itô stochastic differential equation for the controlled Hamiltonian of the uncertain system is of the form (36)

The asymptotic form of m~(H) and σ~2(H) are similar to equation (32), i.e., (37) where the expressions of μ1 and μ2 are the same as μ¯1 and μ¯2 defined in equation (33) except that s¯ is replaced by s.
Thus, from equation (23) and equations (32) to (37), the asymptotic expression of ~~m(H) can be derived as (38)
Following equations (21) and (22), the maximal Lyapunov exponents of the optimally controlled or uncontrolled system (25) can be calculated approximately as (39) or (40) respectively.

sec.title: 5.2. Case 2: δ > 1
sec.p: In this case, m¯(H) and σ¯2(H) in equation (28) and 〈P1 2/(2R1)+P2 2/(2R2)〉 in equation (31) have the following asymptotic forms: (41) where (42)
Using the same procedure as that in case 1 and letting (43) C2 can be obtained as (44)
The asymptotic expression for the drift coefficient of controlled Hamiltonian is then (45)

Similarly, the approximate maximal Lyapunov exponents of optimally controlled or uncontrolled uncertain system (25) can be obtained as (46) or (47) respectively. The expressions of μ3 and μ4 in equations (45) to (47) are the same as μ¯3 and μ¯4 defined in equation (42) except that s¯ is replaced by s.
It can be seen from equations (39) to (40) or equations (46) to (47) that νc < νu in both cases if f1 > 0, R1, R2 > 0 or f2 > 0, R1, R2 > 0.

Numerical results have been obtained for system (25) with parameter values: k¯1=k¯2=1.0, a¯=1.0, b¯=0.5, α¯1=α¯2=0.01, β¯1=β¯2=0.01, e¯1=e¯3=1.0, e¯2=e¯4=0.5, δ = 0.5, D = D1 = D2 = D3 = D4 = 0.5, f1 = 0.3, R1 = R2 = 1.0, λk1=λk2=λa=λb=λα1=λα2=λβ1=λβ2 =λe1=λe2=λe3=λe4=2.5.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: The robustness of the feedback stabilization of quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian systems with parametric uncertainty has been investigated. First, the nominal system, i.e., the quasi non-integrable Hamiltonian system with average parameters, was asymptotically stabilized, with probability one, by a feedback control. The control law was obtained by using a procedure based on the stochastic averaging method, the stochastic dynamical programming principle and the expression for the Lyapunov exponent. Then, the absolute value of the variation coefficient of the Lyaponov exponent of a controlled system with parametric uncertainty was calculated and compared to the variation coefficients of uncertain parameters. Numerical results showed that the feedback stabilization proposed in (Zhu, 2004b) is quite robust with respect to parameter uncertainty. The procedure to evaluate robustness proposed in this paper can also be used in other circumstances. Instead of the variation coefficient of the Lyapunov exponent, the variation coefficient of the other key index such as the control effectiveness, can be calculated and compared to the variation coefficients of uncertain parameters. Also this procedure, based on sensitivity analysis of variation coefficients, can be used to identify the most important uncertain parameter. Thus, this procedure may become a useful alternative method to study robustness besides the classic methods.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant Nos. 10932009, 11002077 and 11072212, the Zhejiang Provincial Natural Science Foundation under Grant No. Y7080070. The support is gratefully acknowledged.
